timeline.bodyText: We can't change public API.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Fixed. Please take a look
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Why is this in initializeManagementCenterTaskFactories method? We can maybe create initializeSqlTaskFactories.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Not really part of this PR, but since we only use set and get, we can replace this with a volatile field.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Agree, but as you mentioned, this is not part of this PR
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: null should be returned if no member is available, not if we're lazy to find one.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: I am not sure I understand what you mean. This is a static load balancer that always returns the same member. If this member doesn't happen to be a data member, we return null.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: I think it would be better to throw in this case. By setting the StaticLB one asks that all traffic goes to a specific member, but here we return null which in turn will go to some data member.
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText:
This is OK, since traffic may go to another member for many reasons:

If smart routing is disabled
If the member that is set is no longer reachable
Now we add the third case - if the added member is not a data member
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: In other words, there is no such semantics, that forces us to use a specific member. Load balancer is a hint.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: We could declare the return type as Set<UUID>. We actually only call contains on the returned value, a Set indicates that it's designed for that.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Changed to Set
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: We probably should say just "Client cannot be reached", a client is not a member.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText:
This is a fallback code that's used when the load balancer returned null, even though it should return null only if there's no member available. But it's also a fallback when the load balancer doesn't implement the nextDataMember method, and in this case we should find the first data member.
What if the first member returned by the iterator isn't a data member? A user upgrading to 4.2 that has a custom LB can get random "Client must be connected to at least one data member to execute SQL queries" errors.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: It's also used for non-smart client - can such client be connected to a lite member? Won't SQL work at all in that case?
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText:
Not really. LB is only used when smart routing is enabled (see isSmartRoutingEnabled check). Otherwise, we always use the very first member connection (aka "unisocket" client).
@sancar could you please give your comments on the correct behavior?
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Reworked the connection handling so that dataMember=true will return a connection to a data member, even if it is not the first one.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Should be Set<UUID> also here
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Fixed, now Set is used.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: Fixed, now parameters are non-null.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: Simplified as you suggested.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText:
So a unısocket client that is connected to a lite member can not run a query?
This is not suited to our unisocket client behavior. Our unisocket clients should be able to operate same regardless of the member type they are connected to.
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText:
You can check CreateProxyMessageTask. It is one of the places that we explicitly redirect to a data member.
The partition-based ones solve the problem automatically since they will run on their partition owner anyway. Even if we invoke the operation on a lite member, the invocation system redirects it to the partition owner.
replies.author: sancar

replies.bodyText:
Yes, SQL may not work if there lite members in the topology. This is ok for the beta stage at least. Lite member support might be added in the future if we see a demand from users.
This limitation will be mentioned explicitly in the product's documentation.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: I think it's pretty bad that it will fail to work randomly, depending on the member the non-smart client happens to connect. Users might try it and see that it works and then have this misleading error at runtime. In that case we should disallow non-smart clients entirely.
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText:
Documentation solves this. Again - we do not support lite members not because we are lazy, or because we do not understand the implications. This is a necessary measure given the huge scope.
Moreover, in the current PR, we iterate over all members to find the data member for SQL. The flakiness you mentioned is only possible if a user will toggle the member's state back and forth. This is extremely unlikely.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText:
Iterating all connections does not help unisocket client. It will only have one connection. If the client disconnect from data member and connects to lite member, then it will fail.
If this is the decision, we basically say that for the uniscoket client, if you use query, your cluster should not contain a lite member. For the smart client, I agree that the problem is very unlikely to occur.
replies.author: sancar

timeline.bodyText: Both serialization service and client protocol have built-in UUID support. If the only purpose of these High and Low part splits is to support them, I think you can just use UUID instead.
timeline.author: asimarslan

replies.bodyText:
protocol schema will redirect you if you configure it on the protocol side.
https://github.com/hazelcast/hazelcast-client-protocol/blob/master/schema/protocol-schema.json#L26
replies.author: asimarslan

replies.bodyText: UUID content is inlined into the QueryId to reduce the amount of litter. Real UUIDs are rarely extracted from this object. We only do equals/hashCode on hot paths.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: @devozerov I understand the optimization but UUID is a common class that we use. This will be an exception to how we represent it. I would prefer using UUID for the sake of readability.
replies.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: Let me highlight this once again - QueryId is not UUID. We use two UUID-s to guarantee its uniqueness, but other than that it is mostly an opaque blob.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText:
This way of this UUID usage does not match to protocol style. Not all languages use to high low split of a UUID as java.
MemberID is already created somewhere on the member, you don't need to split it for litter optimization. let the protocol encode/Decode it.
For the localId, how many local id's are created in the system? if they are per query, I don't think you should worry about the litter it creates.
We already use UUID in memberId and listenerRegistrationId etc, which are also infrequent.
I understand you want to optimize it in the best way possible but protocol definition is also an important part of our architecture. Moreover, we cannot change the protocol when we publish it.
replies.author: asimarslan

replies.bodyText:
Colleagues, I would like to emphasize one more time what is the nature of query ID. From the client perspective, it is an opaque blob that is passed back and forth. From the server perspective, this is an object that serves multiple purposes, such as 1) guaranteeing cluster-wide uniqueness; 2) providing an ability to find the originator member ID without remote requests.
The design of the client protocol cannot enforce the content of this object, because client doesn't use any features of it, while the server does. Therefore, it cannot be UUID.
On the other hand, I share your concerns about future protocol changes. So I propose the other solution - to change it to String. This would be a good choice from the protocol perspective for an opaque object. If we would like to change the content of this object on the server, the client protocol will not be affected.
I merged these changes to the PR, please take a look.
replies.author: devozerov
asimarslan

replies.bodyText:
I used to think that QueryId was good solution, but now I think that String is better.
As explained before, the query ID is completely opaque to the client, I.e. it is only passed back and forth. String representation has two advantages over QueryId:

It is more stable - we can change the server-side representation without breaking protocol compatibility
It makes client implementation simpler. Consider that we will have SQL implemented in many clients in future. All of them would have to implement a custom object that does zero useful work

That said, IMO String is good enough. Also please note that there is no parsing on the sever side. We convert QueryId to String once (see QueryId.unparse) and then use this String as a key. There should be no negative performance impact from this.
WDYT?
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText:
This does not seem correct. We are not using Data for builtin IdentifiedDataSerializable objects on our protocol as much as possible. It is hard to define what is Data in the protocol. More importantly, they don't support evolution, it is very likely to make a mistake.
I see that Row is an interface. Which Row implementations can we return to the client?
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: I'll change it to List<Data>. There is no model for a row at the moment.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Fixed. Now List<Data> is used to represent row values. Please take a look.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText:
I could not find the cleanup code for the case where a client lefts the cluster without closing the query.
You can use ClientEndpoint.addDestroyAction(UUID registrationId, Callable<Boolean> removeAction); for this.
A client enndpoint is removed and all desrtoy actions are called when the assocaiated connection is disconnected. Since the queries are desinged to be sticky it looks like a good fit.
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: And can we have a test to verify that cleanups are done correctly?
replies.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: I see that QueryClientStateRegistry.update is used for this purpose. I think, our standard solution with ClientEndpoint addDestroyAction is enough for this. What do you think ?
replies.author: sancar

replies.bodyText:
Please see:
com.hazelcast.sql.impl.client.QueryClientStateRegistry#update
com.hazelcast.sql.SqlErrorClientTest#testCursorCleanupOnClientLeave
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText:
ClientEndpoint addDestroyAction looks heavier to me - one have to register it for every request, and also be careful to deregister it properly.
The key observation is that majority of requests will be completed normally, without client disconnects. I think the current approach handles it better - we do no do any additional actions for the most queries.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Ok. Fair enough.
replies.author: sancar

timeline.bodyText: Is permission left null on purpose? I think, SQL permissions are important.
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText:
We do not have a security model yet. Given that an SQL script could trigger any kind of action (e.g. read from several maps, or start Jet job, etc), it is impossible to define the required permissions on that level. The permissions will be known after parsing only.
Meanwhile, we may add a global flag to disable SQL on the member, but this is out of scope of this PR.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: I think we may define a global "query" permission that will govern whether the user can execute any query or not. And more deep integration will be implemented later.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Added the sql permission, modeled after the transaction permission.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: for the method name, we usually use the user API method name. So should it be query?  And note that related tests are on the enterprise repo. Make sure that you have SecurityInterceptor and permission tests for the new use case.
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: I can change it to query, but what is the goal of this? From the user perspective, he executes a query, but internally it is translated into several different commands, that are not directly mapped to the public API. Moreover, the result of this operation contains internal objects, which also highlights that this is not a direct API call.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText:
Well, we don't really have a clear answer. In the end, whatever you choose must be documented clearly. We select it as same as the public method name to make it more intuitive. Not sure what to do when it is multiple requests per API call.
Just be aware that what you choose here is also a public API and needs to be documented.
replies.author: sancar

timeline.message:
1) Added more tests for server-side cursor cleanup
2) Reworked protocol page representation from List<Data> to List<List<Data>
3) Made query parameters non-nullable in the protocol
4) Several other minor changes

timeline.bodyText: Typo: double type?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Not sure that I got why do we need to convert the result to Data if we are already on the client?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: This code is invoked on the member
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Shall we move it then somewhere to the member related class?
replies.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: Makes sense. Moved to the com.hazelcast.sql.impl.state package.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: If an exception is thrown from service.close(connection, queryId) then we still mark the iterator as closed while it is not?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: The only reason for the exception here is a broken connection. If it is broken, there is no sense trying to keep the result opened, because no more rows could be fetched anyway.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: What is the meaning for the cursorBufferSize=0?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: These methods are not used in this PR, they are needed by JDBC. Removed them for now to avoid confusion.

timeline.bodyText: Shall we add if(closed) check here as well?
timeline.author: petrpleshachkov

replies.bodyText: This method first invokes hasNext that does this check.

timeline.bodyText: Why do we return the last member in this case?

replies.bodyText:
I do not know, this is just a copy-paste from the next() method to let the test compile. There is this comment above:
//try to force second member to connect when exist

timeline.bodyText: There is no need for SqlExecuteResponse object anymore here.

replies.bodyText: Fixed.

timeline.bodyText: There is no need for SqlFetchResponse  object anymore here.

timeline.bodyText:
Would it be possible to use List<Data> instead of SqlPageRow here. And also in the protocol ?
It would eliminate the need for creating a new type in the protocol, as well as creating extra objects here.
In the protocol, we may also eliminate SqlPage in the protocol and put the last boolean as one of the response params.
timeline.author: sancar

replies.bodyText: Removed SqlPage from the protocol, although it is still used in the server-side part, because we need to return rows and a flag anyway.
replies.author: devozerov

You can eliminate the need for creating SqlFetchResponse class by returning page or error directly.
encodeResponse method could act accordingle by checking if response is instanceOf Exception or not.

replies.bodyText: It will make the code harder to follow because we will use different ways of returning results for execute and fetch commands.

timeline.message:
1) Fixed if-statement in the QueryClientStateRegistry
2) Changed query ID to String in the protocol
3) Removed unnecessary allocations in SqlClientService
Execute SQL tasks in the query executor
Removed SqlPage from the protocol level.

timeline.author: viliam-durina

timeline.message: Added missing element to YAML config.
Use Collection<Collection<Data>> instead of List<List<Data>> for Java protocol definitions.
Returned back QueryId to the protocol.
Fixed the design doc reflect that QueryId is no longer a string.
